items.title: Document title
items.help_text: The title of the metadata document (which will usually be the same as the element "Title" in the "Table description / Title statement" section). The metadata document is the metadata file (XML or JSON file) that is being generated.

items.title: Document ID
items.help_text: A unique identifier for the table's metadata document. This identifier must be unique in the catalog where the metadata are intended to be published. Ideally, the identifier should also be unique globally. This is different from the "Primary ID" in section "Table description / Title statement", although it is good practice to generate identifiers that establish a clear connection between these two identifiers. The Document ID could also include the metadata document version identifier. For example, if the "Primary ID" of the table is “TBL_0001”, the Document ID could be “IHSN_TBL_001_v1.0” if the metadata are produced by the IHSN and if this is version 1.0 of the metadata. Each organization should establish systematic rules to generate such IDs. A validation rule can be set (using a regular expression) in user templates to enforce a specific ID format. The identifier may not contain blank spaces.

items.title: Metadata producers

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the person or organization who produced the metadata or contributed to its production.

props.title: Abbreviation
props.help_text: The abbreviation (or acronym) of the organization that is referenced in "Name".

props.title: Affiliation
props.help_text: The affiliation of the person or organization mentioned in "Name".

props.title: Role
props.help_text: The specific role of the person or organization mentioned in "Name" in the production of the metadata.

items.help_text: The metadata producer is the person or organization with the financial and/or administrative responsibility for the processes whereby the metadata document was created. This is a "Recommended" element. For catalog administration purposes, information on the producer and on the date of metadata production is useful.

items.title: Production date
items.help_text: The date the metadata on this table was produced (not distributed or archived), preferably entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD or YYY-MM). A validation rule can be set in user templates to enforce a date format. This is a "Recommended" element, as information on the producer and on the date of metadata production is useful for catalog administration purposes.

items.title: Version
items.help_text: The version of the metadata document (not the version of the table itself).

items.title: Primary ID
items.help_text: A unique identifier of the table. The "Primary ID" (also referred to as IDNO) is a unique identification number used to identify the table. A unique identifier is required for cataloguing purpose, so this element is declared as "Required". The identifier will allow users to cite the table properly. The identifier must be unique within the catalog. Ideally, it should also be globally unique. A Digital Object Identifier (DOI) can be used. for the study. Alternatively, the "Primary ID" can be constructed by an organization using a consistent scheme. Note that the schema allows you to provide more than one identifier for a same table (in element "Other identifiers"); a catalog-specific identifier is thus not incompatible with a globally unique identifier like a DOI. A validation rule can be set (using a regular expression) in user templates to enforce a specific ID format. A validation rule can be set (using a regular expression) in user templates to enforce a specific ID format. The identifier may not contain blank spaces.
items.name: idno

items.title: Other identifiers
items.help_text: This repeatable element is used to enter identifiers (IDs) other than the "Primary ID" (IDNO). It can for example be a Digital Object Identifier (DOI). The "Primary ID" can be repeated here (the "Primary ID" does not provide a "Type" parameter, so if a DOI or other standard ID type is used as main identifier, it is recommended to repeat it here with the identification of the type).

props.title: Type
props.help_text: The type of identifier. For example: “DOI”, or "ISBN".

props.title: Identifier
props.help_text: The identifier itself.

items.title: Table number
items.help_text: The table number will usually begin with the word “Table” followed by a numeric identifier such as: Table 1 or Table 2.1 etc. Different publications may use different ways to reference a table.

items.title: Title
items.name: title
items.help_text: The title of the table. The title provides a brief description of the content of the table. It should be concise and include the key elements shown in the table. There are varying styles for writing a table title. A consistent style should be applied to all tables published in a catalog. Pay attention to the consistent use of capitalization in the title.

items.title: Subtitle
items.help_text: The table subtitle can be used when there is a need to distinguish characteristics of the table. A subtitle can provide further descriptive or explanatory content to the table. Pay attention to the consistent use of capitalization in the subtitle.

items.title: Alternate title
items.help_text: A title that may be given to the table, other than the main title entered in "Title". This element will rarely be used.

items.title: Abbreviated title
items.help_text: An abbreviated title, which can for example be an acronym (but not the table number, which should be captured in "Table number") by which the table may be referred to. This element will rarely be used.

items.title: Translated title
items.help_text: The translated title element is usually used to provide a translation of the title in cases where more than one official language is used or if a publication is widely disseminated in two languages. Special characters should be properly displayed, such as accents and other stress marks or different alphabets.

items.title: Authoring entity

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of person(s) or organization responsible for the production and content of the table.

props.title: Affiliation
props.help_text: The affiliation of the person(s) or organization(s) mentioned in name.

props.title: Abbreviation
props.help_text: The abbreviation (acronym) of the organization mentioned in name.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URI can be a link to the website, or the email address, of the authoring entity mentioned in name.

props.title: Author ID
props.help_text: The author identifier in a registry of academic researchers such as the Open Researcher and Contributor ID (ORCID).

props.title: Type
props.help_text: The type of identifier, i.e. the identification of the registry that assigned the author’s identifier, e.g. “ORCID”.

props.title: ID
props.help_text: The identifier of the author in the registry mentioned in type.

items.help_text:
The authoring entity identifies the person(s) or organization(s) responsible for the production of the table. An authoring entity is identified by its name, affiliation, abbreviation, URI, and author’s identifiers (if any).

- Author ID": The author identifier in a registry of academic researchers such as the Open Researcher and Contributor ID (ORCID).
   * Type: The type of identifier, i.e. the identification of the registry that assigned the author’s identifier, e.g. “ORCID”.
   * ID: The identifier of the author in the registry mentioned in type.

items.title: Contributors

props.title: Name
props.help_text: Name of the person, corporate body, or agency responsible for the work's substantive and intellectual content. If a person, invert first and last name and use commas.

props.title: Abbreviation
props.help_text: Abbreviation

props.title: Role
props.help_text: Title of the person (if any) responsible for the work's substantive and intellectual content.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: URI

items.help_text:
This set of elements identifies the person(s) and/or organization(s), other than the authoring entity, who contributed to the production of the table.

- Name: The name of the contributor (person or organization).
- Affiliation: The affiliation of the contributor mentioned in name. This could be a government agency, a university or a department in a university, etc.
- Abbreviation: The abbreviation for the institution which has been listed as the affiliation of the contributor.
- Role: The specific role of the contributor mentioned in name. This could for example be "Research assistant”, “Technical specialist”, “Programmer”, or “Reviewer”.
- URL: A URL (link to a website, or email address) for the contributor mentioned in name.

items.title: Publisher

props.title: Name
props.help_text: Name of the person, corporate body, or agency responsible for the work's substantive and intellectual content. If a person, invert first and last name and use commas.

props.title: Abbreviation
props.help_text: Abbreviation

props.title: Role
props.help_text: Title of the person (if any) responsible for the work's substantive and intellectual content.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: URI

items.help_text:
The entity responsible for publishing the table.

- Name: The name of the publisher (person or organization).
- Affiliation: The affiliation of the publisher. This could be a government agency, a university or a department in a university, etc.
- Abbreviation: The abbreviation for the institution which has been listed as the affiliation of the publisher.
- Role: The specific role of the publisher (this element is unlikely to be used as the role is obvious).
- URL: A URI (link to a website, or email address) of the publisher.

items.title: Date created
items.help_text: The date the table was created. It is recommended to enter the date in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD or YYYY-MM or YYYY). The date the table is created refers to the date that the output was produced and considered ready for publication.

items.title: Date published
items.help_text: The date the table was published. It is recommended to enter the date in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD or YYYY-MM or YYYY). If the table is contained in a document (report, paper, book, etc.), the date the table is published is associated with the publication date of that document. If the table is found in a statistics yearbook for example, then the publication date will be the date the yearbook was published.

items.title: Date last modified
items.help_text: The date the table was last modified. It is recommended to enter the date in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD or YYYY-MM or YYYY). Modifications, revisions, or re-publications of the table are recorded in this element.

items.title: Version
items.help_text: The version of the table refers to the published version of the table. If for some reason, data in a published table are revised, then the version of the table is captured in this element.

items.title: Description
items.help_text: A brief “narrative” description of the table. The description can contain information on the content, purpose, production process, or other relevant information.

items.title: Table columns
items.help_text:
The columns description is composed of the column spanner and the column heads. Columns spanners group the column heads together in a logical fashion to present the data to the user. Not all columns presented in a table will have a column spanner. The column spanners can become quite complicated; when a table is documented, the information found in the column spanner and heads can be merged and edited. What matters is not to document the exact structure of the table, but to ensure that the text of the spanners and heads is included in the metadata as this text will be used by search engines to find tables in data catalogs.

- Label: The labels of the table columns (or column captions) are vital for discoverability. The column labels will include both column spanners and column headers. Columns spanners are captions that join various column headers together.
- Variable name: This refers to the name of the variables found in the dataset (typically microdata) used to produce the table. The objective of this optional field is to help establish a link between the source dataset and the table, to foster reproducibility.
- Dataset: This refers to the dataset (typically microdata) used to produce the table. If the dataset is available in a catalog and has a unique identifier (DOI or other), this identifier can be entered here. Alternatively, the title of the dataset or a permanent URI can be provided.

props.title: Variable name
props.help_text: Variable name

items.title: Table rows
items.help_text: Like the column spanner and column heads, the "Table rows" section is composed of the stub head and stubs (row captions). The stubs are the captions of the rows of data and the stub head is the label that groups the rows together in a logical fashion. As for "Table columns" , the information found in the stubs can be merged and edited to be optimized for clarity and discoverability.

props.title: Label
props.help_text: As with the column labels, the content in "Label" is designed to include the stub head, stubs and any captions included.

props.title: Variable name
props.help_text: As with the column variables, this optional element is reserved to identify those variables found in the source dataset that are associated with the row of data.

props.title: Dataset
props.help_text: This refers to the dataset (typically microdata) used to produce the table. If the dataset is available in a catalog and has a unique identifier (DOI or other), this identifier can be entered here. Alternatively, the title of the dataset or a permanent URI can be provided. Note also that the schema provides a "Data sources" element (see below) to describe in more detail the sources of data. The content of the dataset element must be compatible with the information provided in that other element.

items.title: Table footnotes
items.help_text: Table footnotes

items.title: Series
items.help_text:
Tables may be organized into series, typically by theme.

- Name: The name (label) of the series.
- Maintainer: The person or organization in charge of maintaining the series. This will often be the same person/organization that produce and publish the table. This optional element will often be ignored.
- URL: A URL to the series information. This optional element will often be ignored.
- Description: A description of the series.

items.title: Statistics
items.help_text:
The table metadata will not contain data. What the statistics element refers to is the type of statistics included in the table. Some tables may only contain counts, such as a table of population by age group and sex (which shows counts of persons; other tables could be counts of households, facilities, or any other observation unit). But statistical tables can contain many other types of summary statistics. This element is used to list these types of statistics.

The use of a controlled vocabulary is recommended. This list could contain (but does not have to be limited to):
Count (frequencies) | Number of missing values | Mean (average) | Median | Mode | Minimum value | Maximum value | Range | Standard deviation | Variance | Confidence interval (95%) - Lower limit | Confidence interval (95%) - Upper limit | Standard error | Sum | Inter-quartile Range (IQR) | Percentile (possibly with specification, e.g., “10th percentile”) | Mean Absolute Deviation | Mean Absolute Deviation from the Median (MADM) | Coefficient of Variation (COV) | Coefficient of Dispersion (COD) | Skewness | Kurtosis | Entropy | Regression coefficient | R-squared | Adjusted R-squared | Z-score | Accuracy | Precision | Mean squared logarithmic error (MSLE)

items.title: Units of observations
items.help_text:
The element provides information on the unit(s) of observations that correspond to the values shown in the table.

- Value: The value is not a numeric value; it is the label (description) of the observation unit, e.g., “individual” or “person”, “household”, “dwelling”, enterprise, “country”, etc.

items.title: Data sources
items.help_text:
The data sources are often cited in the footnote section of a table. The name, Source ID, and URL elements are optional, but at least one of them must be provided.

- Name: The name (title) of the data source. For example, a table data may be extracted from the “Population Census 2020”.
- Abbreviation: The abbreviation (acronym) of the data source.
- Source ID: A unique identifier for the source, such as a Digital Object Identifier (DOI).
- Note: A note that describes how the source was used, possibly mentioning issues in the use of the source.
- URL: A link (URL) to the source dataset.

items.title: Time periods

props.title: Start date
props.help_text: Date in ISO format  (YYYY-MM-DD). Partial dates are supported

props.title: End date
props.help_text: Date in ISO format  (YYYY-MM-DD). Partial dates are supported

items.help_text:
The time periods consists of a list or periods (range of years / quarters / months / days) that the data relate to, preferably entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY, or YYYY-MM, or YYYY-MM-DD). If the data are by quarter, convert them into ISO 8601 format (e.g., first quarter of 2020 would be "from 2020-01 to 2020-03). This is a repeatable field. If the time periods are for example 1990, 2000 to 2004, and 2014 to June 2019, do not enter the time period as a single range 1990-2019 as this would include irrelevant periods. It should be entered as three separate ranges as in the example below. For data that are related to a specific date (for example, the population of a country as of the census day), enter the date in both the from and to fields.

- From: The start date of the time period covered by the table, preferably entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY, or YYYY-MM, or YYYY-MM-DD).
- To: The end date of the time period covered by the table, preferably entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY, or YYYY-MM, or YYYY-MM-DD).

items.title: Universe
items.help_text:
The universe of a table refers to the population (or respondents) covered in the data. It does not have to be a population of individuals; it can for example be a population of households, facilities, firms, groups of persons, or even objects. The description of the universe should clearly inform the data users of inclusions and exclusions that they may not expect.

- Value: A textual description of the universe covered by the data.

items.title: Countries
items.help_text:
This element is used to document the list of countries for which data are in the table. This element serves to assure that the country name and code are easily discoverable and contribute to a virtual national catalog. If the table only refers to part of a country (for example a city), the "Countries" field should still be filled. Another element called "Geographic areas" is provided to capture more detailed information on the table’s geographic coverage.

NOTE: This field refers to the country or countries that the table provides data about. If a table contains for example data on the population of Belgium by country or birth, only "Belgium" will be entered in this element, not the list of countries of birth.

- Name: The name of a country for which data are in the table.
- Code: The code of the country mentioned in name, preferably an ISO 3166 country code.

items.title: Geographic areas
items.help_text:
An itemized list of geographic areas covered by the data in the table, other than the country/countries that must be entered in "Countries".

- Name: The name of the geographic unit.
- Code: The code of the geographic unit mentioned in name.
- Type: The type of geographic unit mentioned in name (e.g., “State”, “Province”, “Town”, “Region”, etc.)

props.title: Location name
props.help_text: Name of the geographic unit e.g. 'World', 'Africa', 'Afghanistan'

props.title: Location code
props.help_text: Code of the geographic unit (for countries, preferred = ISO3 code)

props.title: Type
props.help_text: Type of geographic unit e.g. country, state, region, province etc

items.title: Geographic granularity
items.help_text: A description of the geographic levels for which data are presented in the table. This is not a list of specific geographic areas, but a list of the administrative level(s) that correspond to these geographic areas.

items.title: Bounding boxes

props.title: West
props.help_text: West longitude of the bounding box.

props.title: East
props.help_text: East longitude of the bounding box.

props.title: South
props.help_text: South latitude of the bounding box.

props.title: North
props.help_text: North latitude of the bounding box.

items.help_text: This element is used to define one or multiple geographic bounding box(es), which are the rectangular fundamental geometric description of the geographic coverage of the data. A bounding box is defined by west and east longitudes and north and south latitudes, and includes the largest geographic extent of the dataset’s geographic coverage. The bounding box provides the geographic coordinates of the top left (north/west) and bottom-right (south/east) corners of a rectangular area. This element can be used in catalogs as the first pass of a coordinate-based search. The valid range of latitude in degrees is -90 and +90 for the southern and northern hemisphere, respectively. Longitude is in the range -180 and +180 specifying coordinates west and east of the Prime Meridian, respectively.

items.title: Languages

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the language(s) in which the table is published, preferably extracted from the ISO 639 standardized nomenclature of languages.

props.title: Code
props.help_text: The code of the language, preferably from the ISO 639 code list.

items.help_text: Most tables will only be provided in one language. This is however a repeatable field, to allow for more than one language to be listed.

items.title: Links

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL to an external resource.

props.title: Description
props.help_text: A brief description of the resource.

items.help_text: A list of associated links related to the table.

items.title: API documentation

props.title: Description
props.help_text: This element will not contain the API documentation itself, but information on what documentation is available.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL of the API documentation.

items.help_text: Increasingly, data are made accessible via Application Programming Interfaces (APIs). The API associated with a series must be documented.

items.title: Publications

props.title: Title
props.help_text: The title of the publication (including the producer and the year).

props.title: URL
props.help_text: A link to the publication.

items.help_text: This element identifies the publication(s) where the table is published. This could for example be a Statistics Yearbook, a report, a paper, etc.

items.title: Keywords

props.title: Keyword
props.help_text: The keyword itself.

props.title: Vocabulary
props.help_text: The controlled vocabulary (including version number or date) from which the keyword is extracted, if any.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL of the controlled vocabulary from which the keyword is extracted, if any.

items.help_text: A list of keywords that provide information on the core content of the table. Keywords provide a convenient solution to improve the discoverability of the table, as it allows terms and phrases not found in the table itself to be indexed and to make a table discoverable by text-based search engines. A controlled vocabulary will preferably be used (although not required), such as the UNESCO Thesaurus. The list provided here can combine keywords from multiple controlled vocabularies, and user-defined keywords.

items.title: Themes

props.title: ID
props.help_text: The ID of the theme, taken from a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Theme
props.help_text: The name (label) of the theme, preferably taken from a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Parent ID
props.help_text: The parent ID of the theme (ID of the item one level up in the hierarchy), if a hierarchical controlled vocabulary is used.

props.title: Vocabulary
props.help_text: The name (including version number) of the controlled vocabulary used, if any.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL to the controlled vocabulary used, if any.

items.help_text: A list of themes covered by the table. A controlled vocabulary will preferably be used. Note that themes will rarely be used as the elements topics and disciplines are more appropriate for most uses.

items.title: Topics

props.title: ID
props.help_text: The identifier of the topic, taken from a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Topic
props.help_text: The name (label) of the topic, preferably taken from a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Parent ID
props.help_text: The parent identifier of the topic (identifier of the item one level up in the hierarchy), if a hierarchical controlled vocabulary is used.

props.title: Vocabulary
props.help_text: The name (including version number) of the controlled vocabulary used, if any.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL to the controlled vocabulary used, if any.

items.help_text: Information on the topics covered in the table. A controlled vocabulary will preferably be used, for example the CESSDA Topics classification, a typology of topics available in 11 languages; or the Journal of Economic Literature (JEL) Classification System, or the World Bank topics classification. Note that you may use more than one controlled vocabulary.

items.title: Disciplines

props.title: ID
props.help_text: The identifier of the discipline, taken from a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name (label) of the discipline, preferably taken from a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Parent ID
props.help_text: The parent identifier of the discipline (identifier of the item one level up in the hierarchy), if a hierarchical controlled vocabulary is used.

props.title: Vocabulary
props.help_text: The name (including version number) of the controlled vocabulary used, if any.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL to the controlled vocabulary used, if any.

items.help_text: Information on the academic disciplines related to the content of the table. A controlled vocabulary will preferably be used, for example the one provided by the list of academic fields in Wikipedia.

items.title: Definitions
items.help_text: Definitions or concepts covered by the table.

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name (or label) of the term, indicator, or concept being defined.

props.title: Definition
props.help_text: The definition of the term, indicator, or concept.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: A link to the source of the definition, or to a site providing a more detailed definition.

items.title: Classifications
items.help_text: The element is used to document the use of standard classifications (or “ontologies”, or “taxonomies”) in the table.

props.title: Name
props.help_text: Name (label) of the classification, ontology, or taxonomy.

props.title: Version
props.help_text: Version of the classification, ontology, or taxonomy used in the table.

props.title: Organization
props.help_text: Organization that is the custodian of the classification, ontology, or taxonomy.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: Link to an external resource where detailed information on the classification, ontology, or taxonomy can be obtained.

items.title: Rights
items.help_text: Information on the rights or copyright that applies to the table.

items.title: License
items.help_text:
A table may require a license to use or reproduce. This is done to protect the intellectual content of the research product. The licensing entity may be different from the researcher or the publisher. It is the entity which has the intellectual rights to the table (s) and would grant rights or restrictions on the reuse of the table.

- Name: The name of the license.
- URL: A link to a publicly-accessible description of the terms of the license.

items.title: Citation
items.help_text: A citation requirement for the table (i.e. an indication of how the table should be cited in publications).

items.title: Confidentiality
items.help_text: A published table may be protected through a confidentiality agreement between the publisher and the researcher. It may also determine certain rights regarding the use of the research and the data presented to the table. The data may also present confidential information that is produced for selective audiences. This element is used to provide a statement on any limitations ore restrictions on use of the table based on confidential data or agreements.

items.title: SDC
items.help_text:
Information on statistical disclosure control (SDC) measures applied to the table. This can include cell suppression, or other techniques. Specialized packages have been developed for this purpose, like sdcTable: Methods for Statistical Disclosure Control in Tabular Data and https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/sdcTable/sdcTable.pdf

The information provided here should be such that it does not provide intruders with useful information for reverse-engineering the protection measures applied to the table.

items.title: Contacts
items.help_text:
Users of the data may need further clarification and information. This section may include the name-affiliation-email-URI of one or multiple contact persons. This block of elements will identify contact persons who can be used as resource persons regarding problems or questions raised by the user community. The URI attribute should be used to indicate a URN or URL for the homepage of the contact individual. The email attribute is used to indicate an email address for the contact individual. It is recommended to avoid putting the actual name of individuals. The information provided here should be valid for the long term. It is therefore preferable to identify contact persons by a title. The same applies for the email field. Ideally, a “generic” email address should be provided. It is easy to configure a mail server in such a way that all messages sent to the generic email address would be automatically forwarded to some staff members.

- Name: Name of a person or unit (such as a data help desk). It will usually be better to provide a title/function than the actual name of the person. Keep in mind that people do not stay forever in their position.
- Role: The specific role of name, in regards to supporting users. This element is used when multiple names are provided, to help users identify the most appropriate person or unit to contact.
- Affiliation: Affiliation of the person/unit.
- Email: E-mail address of the person.
- Telephone: A phone number that can be called to obtain information or provide feedback on the table. This should never be a personal phone number; a corporate number (typically of a data help desk) should be provided.
- URL: A link to a website where contact information for name can be found.

items.title: Notes

props.title: Note
props.help_text: The note itself.

items.help_text: The notes provide a space to include observations or open-ended content that may be material in understanding the table, which have not been captured in other elements of the schema.

items.title: Relations
items.help_text: If the table has a relation to other resources (e.g., it is a subset of another resource, or a translation of another resource), the relation(s) and associated resources can be listed in this element.

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The related resource. Recommended practice is to identify the related resource by means of a URI. If this is not possible or feasible, a string conforming to a formal identification system may be provided.

props.title: Type
props.help_text: The type of relationship. The use of a controlled vocabulary is recommended. The Dublin Core proposes the following vocabulary: isPartOf, hasPart, isVersionOf, isFormatOf, hasFormat, references, isReferencedBy, isBasedOn, isBasisFor, replaces, isReplacedBy, requires, isRequiredBy.
